awd_titl_txt: Conference: Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages 50: Austin, TX: April 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
The 50th Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages (LSRL) will be held at the University of Texas at Austin from April 23-25, 2020. The LSRL attracts an international body of scholars, and is a prominent venue for scholarly discussion and dissemination of research findings in the subfields of syntax, semantics, pragmatics, phonology, phonetics, historical linguistics/dialectology, and second language, heritage and bilingual studies as they apply to the Romance languages. LSRL50 will showcase research that employs diverse methods and different types of empirical observations applied to various Romance languages in the evaluation, testing, and revision of linguistic models. The objectives of the conference include promoting a culture of open and shared tools and data, bridging linguistics with STEM disciplines, providing a forum in which scholars of different orientations communicate with one another, and actively involving graduate and undergraduate students from languages and linguistics and from STEM fields in conference activities. The conference consists of 54 refereed oral presentations and 30 selected poster presentations. Five keynote speakers will address multiple sub-disciplines and languages using diverse methods of data collection: fieldwork, laboratory studies, sociolinguistic interviews, archival recordings, and web scraping. In addition, there will be a 'bring your own data' workshop to help participants visualize and explore multilingual language data.
 
Funding from the National Science Foundation will provide partial support for the keynote speakers and the data science workshop convener. Funding will also provide student participation support costs for up to 20 undergraduate students, many of whom come from academic units that serve students of bilingualism and multiculturalism, an interest that reflects the social makeup of Texas and of the U.S. more generally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Funding from the National Science Foundation supported the hosting of the 50th Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages (LSRL), organized by Professors Barbara Bullock, Cinzia Russi, and Almeida Jacqueline Toribio of the University of Texas at Austin.

Due to the pandemic, the in-person conference was cancelled and reorganized into a virtual event, held over a period of 6 days from July 1-3, 2020, and from July 6-8, 2020, in three-hour periods to accommodate an international audience. The conference enjoyed a robust average daily attendance of nearly 200 participants, with attendees from every continent except Antarctica. The program included 66 research presentations delivered in parallel thematic sessions and in poster presentations. In addition to the juried papers, LSLR50 offered two data science workshops: “Wrangling linguistic data with Python,” led by Professor Jacqueline Serigos, and a LaTeX tutorial, led by PhD candidate Luis Avilés González. The program also featured four keynote speakers who represented diverse perspectives and methodologies in the language sciences: psycholinguist Professor David Birdsong, computer scientist Professor Thamar Solorio, sociolinguist and phonetician Professor Zsuzsanna Fagyal, and documentary linguist Professor Patience Epps.

The program emphasized the vast range of empirical contributions that researchers have more recently applied to topics in Romance that had long been treated only from a theoretical perspective. The works presented comprised: laboratory-based experimentation; acoustic and articulatory studies of regional and social variation; on-line and off-line psycholinguistic methodologies applied to topics in Romance; and corpus analyses of diachronic and synchronic variation and change. Aside from adding to the body of research dedicated to the linguistic structure of Romance languages, the program highlighted linguistic issues in language contact and bilingualism with papers on second language and heritage language Romance speakers. The conference facilitated the connection of Romance linguistic with work in STEM fields, with a strong focus in the keynote addresses and workshops on data science approaches to bilingual research in the Romance linguistics, including work on language mixing.

LSRL50 featured extensive engagement with student and extramural communities. A team of five graduate students and six undergraduates from the Departments of Spanish & Portuguese, French & Italian, and Electrical & Computer Engineering assisted in the organization, execution, and dissemination of the results of the online conference. A graduate student assisted in the typesetting and editing of the selected proceedings volume, and the undergraduates worked alongside the PI to create an open bibliographic database of every published paper from the first 50 years of the LSRL. The conference also featured a lecture directed toward bilingual members of the public and parents of children in dual-language education, thus affecting a population that goes beyond those interested in only Romance languages. In addition, the program contained many contributions that focused on variation in Romance, including dialectal variation (for instance Caribbean Spanish, Gascon, Picard, Gallo-Romance) and variation ensuing from speaker differences, offering more inclusive perspectives on Romance languages and their speakers.

The conference thus successfully accomplished the specific goals set forth in the grant proposal: to highlight innovative approaches to classic problems in Romance linguistics; to celebrate major achievements of 50 years of research; provide forums in which scholars from different orientations communicate with one another; to showcase research that uses different types of data; to bridge linguistics with STEM fields; to promote a culture of shared tools and data; and to engage students in scholarly linguistic activities. The volume of the selected proceedings entitled “A half century of Romance Linguistics: Selected Proceedings of the 50th Linguistic Symposium of Romance Linguistics” was published through Language Science Press in 2023, offering the first open access publication of an LSRL proceedings.
